prerequisite.div: High school chemistry or equivalent strongly recommended.

notes.div: Parallel BIOS 101L.

description.div: Analysis of the structure, functions, and interactions of organisms at the molecular, cellular, and individual levels of organization.
Laboratory exercises and experiments that complement material covered in BIOS 101.

prerequisite.div: High school chemistry, or CHEM 109 or parallel.

notes.div: CHEM 109 recommended.

description.div: General introduction to the chemistry of life, cellular organelles, metabolism and reproduction, the structure and expression of DNA and an introduction to patterns of inheritance

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors Program or permission; high school chemistry, or CHEM 109 or parallel.

notes.div: CHEM 109 recommended.

description.div: General introduction to the chemistry of life, cellular organelles, metabolism and reproduction, the structure and expression of DNA and an introduction to patterns of inheritance

notes.div: BIOS 103 is intended for those with a personal professional interest in the life sciences (broadly defined)

description.div: Survey of living organisms, their morphology, life histories, taxonomy, phylogeny, ecology and biogeography. The nature of biological diversity, how that diversity is studied, and the economic importance of various groups of organisms.

prerequisite.div: Admission to the University Honors Program.

notes.div: High school chemistry recommended.

description.div: In-depth survey of biological principles as applied to cells, individuals, and communities.

notes.div: Field work is required.

description.div: Introduction to the plant kingdom and to plants as biological organisms; structure and function of cells, tissues, and organs with emphasis on seed plants; the important processes and concepts of classification, inheritance, evolution, and ecology.

notes.div: Open to freshmen and sophomores; juniors and seniors by permission only.

description.div: Comparative study of microorganisms, principles and applications.

notes.div: Parallel registration in BIOS 112L required.

description.div: Survey of the animal kingdom with emphasis on the evolution, ecology, and behavior of major animal groups.

notes.div: Parallel registration in BIOS 112 required.

description.div: Laboratory exercises and experiments that complement material covered in BIOS 112.

notes.div: ENTO/BIOS 116 may be taken as an optional 1 cr hour lab.

description.div: Fundamental insect biology (anatomy, development, physiology, behavior, ecology and diversity). Economic and medical importance of insects and principles of insect pest management.

Identification of representative orders and families of insects by their anatomy, metamorphosis, habits and habitats. Sight recognition emphasized but dichotomous keys also used. Interrelation of insect and habitats stressed.

notes.div: Offered summers only at Cedar Point Biological Station. Intended primarily for non-science majors and anyone interested in learning more about the natural world. Field trips to sites in western Nebraska.

description.div: Introduction to the animals and/or plants of western Nebraska. Animals and/or plants in their natural environments.

course.title: Introduction to Dentistry and Dental Hygiene

notes.div: BIOS 150 will not count toward a major in biological sciences

description.div: Interest in dentistry, dental hygiene, or other health professions as a career. Terminology, ethics, anatomy, dental specialties and clinical experience.

notes.div: For students interested in a career in clinical laboratory science/medical technology. BIOS 160 will not count toward a major in biological sciences.

description.div: Introduces the pre-clinical laboratory scientist/medical technologist to the profession of clinical laboratory science. Includes lessons in ethics, organization of the medical team, professionalism, automation, medical terminology, hematology, blood bank, clinical chemistry, and medical microbiology.

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors Program or by invitation.

notes.div: University Honors Seminar 189H is required of all students in the University Honors Program.

description.div: Topic varies.

notes.div: BIOS 203 will not count toward a major in biological sciences.

description.div: Relevance of biological science to society and its environment examined through readings, guest lecturers, and discussion.

course.title: Genetics, Molecular and Cellular Biology Laboratory

description.div: Series of lab exercises to introduce principles of genetic, molecular and cellular biology. Experiments done using model systems to identify, map and clone genes; analyze gene products and expression; and fractionate cell components.
Inheritance and regulation of genes in animals, plants and bacteria and model genetic organisms. Genes examined from a classical, molecular and population viewpoint.

notes.div: BIOS 103 recommended.

description.div: Introduction to the principles and processes of ecology and evolution. Structure and dynamics of populations and communities; biotic and abiotic interactions; mechanisms of evolutionary change; natural selection; adaptation; and speciation.

prerequisite.div: BIOS 101 and 101L, or BIOS 102 or equivalent; parallel BIOS 213L.

description.div: Elementary survey of the basic functional systems of the human body: the muscular, nervous, receptor, circulatory, respiratory, digestive, excretory, endocrine, and reproductive systems.

prerequisite.div: BIOS 101 and 101L, or BIOS 102 or equivalent; parallel BIOS 213.

description.div: Laboratory exercises and experiments that complement material covered in BIOS 213.

notes.div: Cadaver prosections are studied in the lab. BIOS 214 is 'Letter Grade Only'.

description.div: Introduction to the major organ systems of the human body including skeletal, major muscle, nervous, digestive, circulatory, excretory, and reproductive systems. Anatomical structures as they pertain to clinical anatomy.

prerequisite.div: High school biology and chemistry. BIOS 101 and 101L, or 102 or equivalent recommended.

description.div: Plant breeding theory and technique. Application of genetic principles to plant improvement. Experience with breeding agronomic and horticultural plant species to illustrate plant mating systems and breeding principles.

prerequisite.div: 4 hrs biological sciences, and MATH 101 or 103.

notes.div: BIOS 220 is not open to students who have completed BIOS 207. BIOS 220 will not count toward a major in BIOS.

description.div: Ecology as a quantitative discipline that integrates the life and earth sciences to understand the dynamics of natural and managed ecosystems.

notes.div: May also be offered at Cedar Point Biological Station. Field trips to local ecosystems are required.

description.div: Field and laboratory experiments in terrestrial and aquatic ecology.

course.title: Ecological Issues in the Great Plains

notes.div: BIOS 232 is not open to students who have completed BIOS 220. BIOS 232 wil not count toward a major in biological sciences.

description.div: Basic concepts in ecology, including comparison of major world ecosystems, especially the Great Plains. Interplay of ecological principles and human activities.

div.strong: Provides a broad overview of bioinformatics. Shows how bioinformatics can help solving problems in biological research. Covered topics: biological databases, molecular biology tools, sequence comparison methods, phylogenetic inference, and molecular graphics.

course.title: The Pre-Health Experience for Biological Sciences Majors

prerequisite.div: Sophomore standing; BIOS major; BIOS 213 or 214.

notes.div: Pass/No Pass only. Keep a personal journal and make a class presentation. BIOS 280 will not count toward a major in BIOS.

description.div: Exposure for pre-medical and other pre-health science students to career in health sciences. Shadow a professional and research medically-based careers.

notes.div: Students need not be majors in biological sciences nor necessarily have had extensive biological training.

description.div: Topic varies.

notes.div: A maximum of 3 credit hours may be counted toward the major in BIOS. Before registering, arrangements must be made with a faculty member in BIOS to reach an agreement on the scope and determine the amount of credit for the project.

description.div: Opportunity to participate in work in a research laboratory in order to gain some insight into the philosophy and methods of original research.

prerequisite.div: One semester BIOS and one semester CHEM.

notes.div: Offered fall semester of odd-numbered calendar years.

description.div: Introduction to the principles of toxicology as they apply to environmental contaminants, agri-chemicals, and industrial and naturally occurring chemicals.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs BIOS including BIOS 102 and 206; one semester organic chemistry. BIOS 205 or equivalent, and two semesters organic chemistry recommended.

notes.div: Continuation of BIOS 102.

description.div: The design, execution, and evaluation of scientific experiments that advance the knowledge of cell and molecular biology.

course.title: Survey in Cell and Molecular Biology Research Techniques

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs of biological sciences and permission.

description.div: Intensive practical research experience for students interested in developing laboratory skills. Team-taught by faculty who conduct research in cell and molecular biology and is designed to expose students to the methods that scientists use to investigate and solve research questions.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs biological sciences with an average of B or above, and permission.

notes.div: P/N only.

description.div: Reviews of current literature of general interest; reports of research activities by staff and guest speakers.

prerequisite.div: One year biological sciences, one year general chemistry, and one semester organic chemistry or one semester biochemistry.

notes.div: One semester organic chemistry and one semester biochemistry recommended. Parallel registration in BIOS 313 or 314 recommended. Credit towards the degree can be earned in only one: BIOS 312 or AGRO 360.

description.div: Microbial cell structure, genetics, metabolic and biosynthetic activity, diversity, ecology and evolution including host-microbe interactions.

prerequisite.div: One year each of biological sciences and general chemistry; one semester organic chemistry or biochemistry; BIOS 312 or parallel.

notes.div: One semester of organic chemistry and one semester biochemistry recommended; BIOS 312 parallel recommended. Credit towards the degree may not be earned in both BIOS 313 and 314.

description.div: Microbiology techniques which include recombinant DNA methods used in industry, medicine and research.

prerequisite.div: One year each biological sciences and general chemistry; one semester organic chemistry or biochemistry; and BIOS 312 or parallel.

notes.div: One semester of organic chemistry and one semester biochemistry recommended. BIOS 312 parallel recommended.Credit towards the degree may not be earned in both BIOS 313 and 314.

description.div: Traditional microbiology techniques without recombinant DNA methods.

Gametogenesis, fertilization, cleavage, early development of a number of vertebrates, and the development of specific organ systems. Includes a three-hour lab in which the morphological aspects of development are illustrated on slides and in which some modern techniques used in experimental mammalian development are introduced.

div.span: Case studies are structured around preparation for subsequent independent research (BIOS 498 or MATH 496).

Introduction to biological literature, applied mathematics, computer programming, and/or statistical techniques relevant to particular questions in ecology, evolution, and behavior. Typical mathematical topics include discrete dynamics, systems of differential equations, matrix algebra, or statistical inference and probability.

prerequisite.div: BIOS 102; one year general chemistry and one semester organic chemistry.

notes.div: Recommended parallel: BIOS 206 or BIOC 313.

description.div: Fundamental concepts in virology including basic features of structure, evolution, diseases, replication cycles and virus-host interactions.

notes.div: PLPT 300 is not an IS course and may not be used for D/F removal in PLPT 369. Credit towards the degree may be earned in only one of PLPT 300 or 369.

description.div: Introduction to the study of plant diseases including relation of plant disease to crop production, environment, and man. Examples and demonstrations emphasize horticultural and agronomic crops of Nebraska.

prerequisite.div: PSYC 181 and BIOS 101/101L or their equivalents.

description.div: Critical introduction into methods and concepts useful in analyzing the biological basis of animal behavior. Topics surveyed are the physiological, genetic, developmental, and environmental mechanisms controlling behavior in various species of animals including humans.
Major groups of economically important plants including food crops, wood, medicinal plants and ornamentals. Evolution, cultivation, processing and uses of the plant.
Comparative study of the morphology and natural history of invertebrate animals; emphasis on phylogenetic relationships.

Emphasis on parasitic diseases of humans. Impact of parasitism on societies considered in addition to the clinical consequences for infected individuals. Means of transmission, diagnosis, and treatment considered in respect to recent technological advances in production of monoclonal antibodies and genetic engineering. Nature and biological significance of parasitism are viewed in terms of prospects for control.

notes.div: BIOS/NRES 386 requires field trips and includes trips outside of normal classtime.

description.div: Evolutionary origin and relationships, natural history, and ecological adaptations of vertebrates. Comparative form and function, particularly of bone and muscle systems among and the diversity within vertebrate groups.

notes.div: BIOS 388 has required assigned readings.

description.div: Evolutionary development and comparative structure of the chordate organ systems, including dissections of the dogfish, salamander, and cat.

notes.div: Open only to students who expect to become teaching assitants in anatomy or physiology

description.div: A combination of academic work and instruction in the anatomy or physiology laboratories in biological sciences: cadaver dissection or work with physiological equipment; assist in the instruction of anatomical and physiological concepts.

notes.div: May be repeated for credit under different topics.

description.div: Critical reading and discussion of literature on topics dealing with the biological bases of behavior.

notes.div: Specifics of requirements to be arranged with surpervising faculty member. BIOS 395 will not count toward a major in BIOS. Pass/No Pass only.

description.div: Combination of work outside the University and academic work in biological sciences arranged through the Career Services Office.

prerequisite.div: Enrollment in the biological sciences honors program.

notes.div: Enrollment in the biolgical sciences honors program

description.div: Special topics in biology.

prerequisite.div: Open to candidates for degrees with distinction or enrollment in the biological sciences honors program.

description.div: Independent research leading to an honors thesis and exam in accordance with the College's degrees with distinction procedure.

notes.div: ENTO 406/806 is offered spring semester of odd numbered calendar years. ENTO 406/806 is also offered on the internet via the World Wide Web (WWW) in the spring semester of odd-numbered calendar years.

description.div: Biotic and abiotic factors as they influence insect development, behavior, distribution, and abundance.
Regulation and timing of macromolecular synthesis during the cell cycle; the genetic autonomy of mitochondria and chloroplasts.

prerequisite.div: BIOS 101 and 101L, or 102 or 112; BIOS 213 or ASCI 240. BIOS 315 recommended.

description.div: Microscopic anatomy of the tissues and organs of major vertebrate species, including humans. Normal cellular arrangements of tissues and organs as related to their macroscopic anatomy and function, with reference to sub-cellular characteristics and biochemical processes. Functional relationships among cells, tissues, organs and organ systems, contributory to organismal well being. General introduction to pathological processes and principles underlying some diseases.

notes.div: Three semesters high school algebra or equivalent recommended.

description.div: Genetic basis of human variation, with emphasis on methods of applying genetic principles to humankind. Genetic ratios in pooled data; population and quantitative genetics; consanguinity; polygenic inheritance; blood types; sex linkage; linkage and crossing over; sex determination; visible chromosome variation; mutation; heredity and environment; eugenics; anthropological genetics; molecular genetics and molecular basis of disease; human genome project.

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors Program or by invitation; BIOS 101 and 101L; BIOS 206.

notes.div: Three semesters high school algebra or equivalent recommended.

description.div: Genetic basis of human variation, with emphasis on methods of applying genetic principles to humankind. Genetic ratios in pooled data; population and quantitative genetics; consanguinity; polygenic inheritance; blood types; sex linkage; linkage and crossing over; sex determination; visible chromosome variation; mutation; heredity and environment; eugenics; anthropological genetics; molecular genetics and molecular basis of disease; human genome project.
Survey of topics in developmental biology, both animal and plant development.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs BIOS including BIOS 206 or equivalent.

description.div: In-depth study of the principles and methodology of genetics, with emphasis on Drosophila: multiple alleles and complex loci, linkage and recombination, chromosome rearrangements, fine structure analysis, sex determination, recombinant DNA, and gene function in development.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs psychology or 12 hrs biological sciences, including PSYC 373 or BIOS 373.

description.div: Relationship of physiological variables to behavior, an introduction to laboratory techniques in neuropsychology.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs BIOS including BIOS 206 or equivalent.

description.div: Molecular basis of genetics. Gene structure and regulation, transposable elements, chromosome structure, DNA replication, and repair mechanisms and recombination.

notes.div: BIOS 423/823 recommended.

description.div: Comprehensive survey of comparative physiology with emphasis on the diversity of adaptations in basic physiological systems and the effects of environmental parameters upon such systems. Comparative physiology of osmoregulation, temperature regulation, metabolism, muscle, central nervous function, and sensory function.

prerequisite.div: BIOS 213 or equivalent and one semester organic chemistry.

description.div: Examination of the more detailed mechanisms operating in selected physiology systems of man and other animals with emphasis on the neural, cardiovascular, renal, and endocrine systems.

Introduction to the use of plants for basic and applied purposes by deliberate manipulation of their genomes; techniques in plant genetic engineering; manipulations of plant development and metabolism; engineering pest, disease, and stress resistance; plants as bioreactors; and environmental and social impacts of plant biotechnology.

notes.div: No computer programming skill is required.

description.div: Basic knowledge and skills needed for general bioinformatics, genomics and proteomics analyses. Various computational analyses including database search, sequence alignment, phylogenetic reconstruction, gene prediction/mining, microarray data analyses and protein structure analyses.
Computer programming, using Perl, as applied to biological sciences, bioinformatics, computational biology, and genomics.

prerequisite.div: BIOS 102 or 206; BIOS 103; BIOS 207 or parallel; or equivalent.

description.div: Principles of phylogenetic inference and emphasis on the application of phylogenetic hypotheses in biology and the biomedical sciences. How inferences derived from phylogenetic trees can be applied in different areas of biological investigation including systematics, biogeography, conservation biology, molecular evolution, genome structure, epidemiology, population biology, ecology, character evolution, behavior, and macroevolution.

notes.div: First course of a two-semester, comprehensive biochemistry course sequence.

description.div: Structure and function of proteins, nucleic acids, carbohydrates and lipids; nature of enzymes; major metabolic pathways; and biochemical energy production.
Continuation of BIOC 431/831. Structural and biochemical aspects of DNA replication and gene expression, and biotechnology.

Introduction to techniques used in biochemical and biotechnology research, including measurement of pH, spectroscopy, analysis of enzymes, chromatography, fractionation of macromolecules, electrophoresis, and centrifugation.

notes.div: Offered every other year beginning spring 2007.

description.div: Biochemical metabolism unique to plants. Relationships of topics previously acquired in general biochemistry to biochemical processes unique to plants. Biochemical mechanisms behind physiological processes discussed in plant or crop physiology.

Analysis and interpretation of the Quaternary period's paleoecological data. Patterns of long-term climate variation. Distribution patterns and responses of organisms and ecosystems to Quaternary environmental change.

prerequisite.div: CHEM 116 or 221 and BIOC/BIOS/CHEM 433/833, or permission.

notes.div: BIOC 437/837 is for advanced undergraduate and beginning graduate students who plan a career in laboratory work within the life sciences

description.div: Practical applications of biochemical methodology to studies in the life sciences. Practical experience with quantitation by spectrophotometry and spectroflurometry, chromatographic and electrophoretic fractionation of proteins and nucleic acids, detection of biomolecules by immunological and DNA hybridization techniques, and analysis of data with a microcomputer.

prerequisite.div: CHEM 109 or 113; 12 hrs geology or biological sciences.

description.div: Chemical cycling at or near the earth's surface, emphasizing interactions among the atmosphere, biosphere, geosphere and hydrosphere. Modern processes, the geological record, and human impacts on elemental cycles.

prerequisite.div: BIOS 312 and either 313 or 314, or permission.

description.div: Molecular approaches to the study of prokaryotic cell structure and physiology, including growth, cell division, metabolism, and alternative microbial life styles.

prerequisite.div: BIOS 312 and either 313 or 314, or permission.

description.div: Fundamental principles involved in host-microorganism interrelationships. Identification of pathogens, isolation, propagation, mode of transmission, pathogenicity, symptoms, treatment, prevention of disease, epidemiology, and methods of control.

prerequisite.div: A course in vertebrate physiology and/or biochemistry.

description.div: Mammalian endocrine glands from the standpoint of their structure, their physiological function in relation to the organism, the chemical nature and mechanisms of action of their secretory products, and the nature of anomalies manifested with their dysfunction.

prerequisite.div: BIOS 206 and one semester organic chemistry.

notes.div: BIOS 102 recommended.

description.div: Fundamental consideration of cellular and humoral mechanisms of immunity, the structure and function of immunoglobulins, antigen-antibody interactions; hypersensitivity; transplantation and tumor immunity; immune and autoimmune disorders.

div.span: 3 hours biological sciences and 3 hours chemistry.
Lectures and discussions of primary literature regarding microorganisms and their role transforming Earth through geologic time.

description.div: Nature, physiology, and interactions of microorganisms in foods. Introduction to food-borne diseases, the effect of food processing systems on the microflora of foods, principles of food preservation, food spoilage, and foods produced by microorganisms. Food plant sanitation and criteria for establishing microbial standards for food products.
The microorganisms in foods and the methods used to study them as discussed in FDST 405/805.

prerequisite.div: One semester microbiology; one semester biochemistry or organic chemistry.

description.div: Soil from a microbe's perspective-growth, activity and survival strategies; principles governing methods to study microorganisms and biochemical processes in soil; mechanisms controlling organic matter cycling and stabilization with reference to C, N, S, and P; microbial interactions with plants and animals; and agronomic and environmental applications of soil microorganisms.

Biological diversity from an evolutionary perspective. The history of the study of human physical growth and biological principles of growth. Genetic, epigenetic and hormonal effects on human and other mammal growth patterns, and environmental factors that influence growth. Effects of nutrition, disease, socio-economic status, pollution, etc. Unique features of human growth in its various stages. How anthropologists interpret variation in growth patterns among human populations and the possible adaptive significance of this variation.
Principles of population dynamics. Management strategies (for consumptive and nonconsumptive fish and wildlife species) presented utilizing principles developed.
A research project designed to give practical experience with a variety of molecular biology techniques.

Series of labs designed to acquaint students with modern techniques used in cell biology labs including plant and animal tissue culture, two-dimensional protein gels, immunoblotting, protein purification techniques, and the use of computers to analyze data.

notes.div: May also be offered at Cedar Point Biological Station.

description.div: Nature and characteristics of populations and communities. Interactions within and between populations in community structure and dynamics. Direct and indirect interactions and ecological processes, competition, predation, parasitism, herbivory, and pollination. Structure, functioning and persistence of natural communities, foodweb dynamics, succession, and biodiversity.

notes.div: May also be offered at Cedar Point Biological Station.

description.div: Plant identification. Field study of the flora in various habitats. Field trips include grassland and woodland vegetation of this region.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; major in the biological sciences; MATH 106 or 107.

description.div: Biological systems, from molecules to ecosystems, are analyzed using mathematical techniques. Strengths and weaknesses of mathematical approaches to biological questions. Brief review of college level math; introduction to modeling; oscillating systems in biology; randomness in biology; review of historically important and currently popular models in biology.

Processes controlling the cycling of energy and elements in ecosystems and how both plant and animal species influence them. Human-influenced global and local changes that alter these cycles and ecosystem functioning.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs biological sciences; BIOS 220; CHEM 109 and 110.

notes.div: Offered even-numbered calendar years.

description.div: Physical, chemical and biological processes that occur in wetlands; the hydrology and soils of wetland systems; organisms occurring in wetlands and their ecology wetland creation, delineation, management and ecotoxicology.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs BIOS, including BIOS/NRES 220/BIOS220x; two semesters CHEM.

notes.div: May also be offered at Cedar Point Biological Station.

description.div: Physical, chemical, and biological processes that occur in fresh water. Organisms occurring in fresh water and their ecology; biological productivity of water and its causative factors; eutroplication and its effects.

notes.div: Geology majors should register for GEOL 439L/BIOS 461L.

description.div: Introduction to the fundamentals of marine ecology and their application to paleoecology.

notes.div: Lab includes several field trips.

description.div: Introduction to animal behavior stressing the ethological approach. Anatomical and physiological bases of behavior, ontogenetic and phylogenetic observations, and the relations of animal behavior studies to genetics, ecology, taxonomy, and evolution. Assigned reading.

Animal behavior stressing an experimental approach. Proximate and ultimate bases of behavior and the relations of behavior to genetics, ecology and evolution investigated using classical methods and state-of-the-art techniques.
Biology of fishes. Factors that affect fishes in the natural environment. Techniques used in the analysis and management of fish populations.

notes.div: Offered in the summer at Cedar Point Biological Station. Requires extensive field work and independent research project.

description.div: Behavior of animals. Stresses methods for testing evolutionary hypotheses under field conditions with emphasis on foraging behavior, animal communication, and animal social systems.

notes.div: Extensive field work is required.

description.div: Structure, function, and distribution of communities. Interaction of different species with their biotic and abiotic environments.
Principles of plant classification, with emphasis on taxonomic procedures, nomenclatural rules, and plant identification. Lab work on taxonomic analysis and plant identification.
The principles and processes of micro- and macroevolution. Mechanisms behind evolutionary change and examples of these processes in a wide variety of organisms.

notes.div: May also be offered at Cedar Point Biological Station.

description.div: Classification, identification, and life histories of algae from freshwater, soil, and air.

notes.div: May also be offered at Cedar Point Biological Station.

description.div: Fossil and living amphibians and reptiles. Anatomy, classification, ecology and evolution.

notes.div: Optional lab (BIOS 475L/875L) by arrangement. May also be offered at Cedar Point Biological Station.

description.div: Review of avian biology. Functional morphology, evolutionary relationships and breeding biology.

notes.div: May also be offered at Cedar Point Biological Station. Field trips are required and may occur outside of scheduled class time. Lab and field time emphasize diversity of mammalian families and species identification of Nebraska mammals.

description.div: Evolution, natural history, ecology, and functional morphology of planetary mammals and mammals of the Northern Great Plains.

prerequisite.div: BIOS 101 and 101L, or 102; BIOS 206 or parallel or CHEM 251 or BIOC 221, or equivalent.

notes.div: Basic statistics recommended.

description.div: Pairwise and multiple alignments, sequence similarity and domain search, distance estimation, phylogenetic methods, gene mining, protein classification and structure. Algorithms used in bioinformatics as well as fundamental concepts of molecular evolution that underlie various bioinformatics methods.
Development, structure, and function of tissues and organs of the higher plants. Relationships of structure to physiology and ecology of plants.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs biological sciences including BIOS 385 and permission.

notes.div: May also be offered at Cedar Point Biological Station.

description.div: Classification, morphology, biology of helminth parasites, chiefly of animals other than man. Includes collection, preparation of specimens, and technique.

notes.div: Offered only at Cedar Point Biological Station.

description.div: Field course in insect taxonomy and biology emphasizing field collection, specimen preparation, classification, and insect natural history.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs biological sciences, including BIOS 213 or equivalent; NUTR 207 or BIOS 214.

notes.div: Exercise science and athletic training majors must take NUTR 207.

description.div: Effects of physical activity on the circulatory, respiratory, and other physiological processes.

notes.div: Offered fall semester of odd-numbered calendar years. Offered summer semester of even-numbered calendar years on the Internet via the World Wide Web (WWW).

description.div: Biology and ecology of aquatic insects.

notes.div: ENTO 402L/802L is offered fall semester of odd-numbered calender years. BIOS 485L/885L and NRES 402L/802L may be offered in the spring semester.

description.div: Identification of aquatic insects to the family level.
Applications of thermodynamics to biochemical phenomena, optical properties of proteins and polynucleotides, and kinetics of rapid reactions.

notes.div: Offered summers only at Cedar Point Biological Station.

description.div: Animal host-parasite relationships, epizootiology, ecology, host distribution, classification, and life cycle stages of animal parasites.

notes.div: Offered summers only at Cedar Point Biological Station.

description.div: Field course in invertebrate community relations stressing on-site observation of community components, natural history, and interactions.

notes.div: May also be offered at Cedar Point Biological Station.

description.div: Fishes, their taxonomy, physiology, behavior, and ecology. Dynamics of fish stocks and factors regulating their production.
Topics vary by term.

notes.div: Four credit hours may be counted toward the undergraduate BIOS major. Before registering, arrangements must be made with a faculty member in BIOS to reach an agreement on the scope and to determine the amount of credit for the project.

description.div: Independent study and laboratory or field investigation of a specific problem.

notes.div: Required for graduation. Pass/No Pass only.

description.div: Completion of a standardized cumulative examination, an exit interview and other assessment activities.
